definition: to hit/to strike/to tap/to rap/to knock/to rip sb off/to overcharge
to cheat/to swindle/to pretend/to feign/to draw sb out/to try to extract information by deceit or bluff

sentences.english: Atttack you, it is for extortionate your money fund.
sentences.chinese: 攻擊你，是爲了敲詐你財錢。

sentences.english: Attempts to paint the family as welfare scroungers have failed.
sentences.chinese: 把這個家庭的人描繪成福利敲詐者的企圖已經失敗了。

sentences.english: He faces trial on extortion charges.
sentences.chinese: 他將因被指控敲詐而受審。

sentences.english: It is a simple blackmailing for the companies working in the region.
sentences.chinese: 這是一個簡單的敲詐勒索的公司在該地區工作。

sentences.english: It's barefaced robbery asking such a high price for that old bicycle!
sentences.chinese: 那輛舊自行車要價如此之高真是無恥的敲詐。

sentences.english: Bob appears to be both vindictive and extortionate.
sentences.chinese: 他顯出一副報復和敲詐的樣子。

sentences.english: What by bribe, and what by extortions, he made enormous sums of money.
sentences.chinese: 他又受賄，又敲詐，因而有了很多錢。

sentences.english: Will a Blackmailer Turn to Murder?
sentences.chinese: 敲詐者會變成殺人犯嗎？

sentences.english: But I don't see how North Korea can use it to extort anything.
sentences.chinese: 但是我不相信朝鮮可以用它來敲詐任何東西。

sentences.english: She was sent to prison for blackmail.
sentences.chinese: 她因犯有敲詐罪被送進監獄。

sentences.english: The blackmailer milked his victims of huge amounts of money.
sentences.chinese: 敲詐者從受害人身上榨取了大量金錢。

sentences.english: The blackmailer will have to be bought off, or he'll ruin your good name.
sentences.chinese: 得花些錢疏通那個敲詐者，否則他會毀壞你的聲譽。

sentences.english: He often extorts money from her.
Mr. Alva says the extortion attempts happened verbally, so nothing is in writing.
sentences.chinese: 阿爾瓦說，敲詐都是口頭進行的，沒有書面證據。

sentences.english: “He blackmailed his own channel, ” Khatib claims.
sentences.chinese: “他敲詐自己所屬的電視臺，”Khatib宣稱。

sentences.english: So you get kind of ripped off a little bit, and there's a lot of people who are not too happy about that.
sentences.chinese: 所以，你有點像是被敲詐勒索了，很多人對此很不滿。

definition: lit. to punch and kick (idiom); to beat up/fig. determined to sort out a problem
to take a risk out of desperation (idiom)
to lure into/to entrap/to trick into/to entice/to induce/to invite/to tempt
lit. a horse that brings trouble to its herd (idiom)/fig. troublemaker/black sheep/rotten apple
to watch with folded arms (idiom); to look on without lifting a finger
to condemn in speech and in writing (idiom)/to denounce by word and pen
